text: (gentle music)
- If people were to say,

why aren't you at that
great company anymore?
You're like, I've got this idea,
and I'm gonna turn it into a company.
And they look at you as if you're crazy.
My name's Katherine McConnell,
and I'm the founder and CEO of Brighte.
(clapper board clicking)

So before Brighte, I
was working in a bank.

I had a really good job
actually, it was a great company,
had been there for about 14 years.

Being an entrepreneur,
starting my own business,

was definitely, definitely
not on the cards.

In my day job, I was
speaking to solar installers
around the country,

who wanted to sell solar
to their customers,

and wanted to remove that
barrier of the upfront price.

And so it was this huge friction
that I was hearing about,
and this huge opportunity.
That did turn into a business plan,
that I worked on for about six months.
I'd get up at 3:30 in the morning,

and work for a couple of
hours before the kids woke up.

I saw it had potential to
impact millions of people,

and so it had to involve
leaving the day job,

and going into the unknown,
and really taking a chance.
We were able to get our house revalued,

and we were able to create
some equity in the home.
That increased our mortgage repayments,

that meant that I had no salary
to contribute to the family.

I felt that that was a
real sacrifice my husband
and my kids were making.
At the beginning of Brighte's journey,

we were able to use the
AWS Activate program.
What we were able to get was credits
for different AWS services.
Using that enabled us to move faster,
and use that money that we'd saved
to hire an extra engineer.
We were building the app

and the background systems
for about nine months.

Through that I was able
to get two people there,

who wanted to put solar and
some power walls on their home.
And then it was a month later
that we actually turned it on live,

and then we expanded it
to another and another,
and AWS supports our business
by providing cloud infrastructure,

and also hosting services
that are used by the business,
and particularly important as we scale.
We'd crack open a bottle of sparkling,
when we could afford it, some champagne.

We'd write the date and
the event on the cork,

the milestones reflect things
like our first customer,

or reaching a hundred million
dollars in applications,

or at one point I had
so many corks on my desk

that someone in the team
made me a little box

to put them all in, and
they're a fantastic memory
of our journey so far.

I probably was just
signed to be a founder,

because I had this crazy,
unwavering conviction
that this was gonna work.
You could be seen as crazy

for having that amount
of convictional belief,

but I intrinsically
felt that, and still do.
(gentle music)
